instruction: 401k with paltry match or SPY ETF?
output: I think you understood much of what I say, in general. Unfortunately, I didn't follow Patches math.  What I gleen from your summary is a 1% match to the 10% invested, but a .8% expense. The ETF VOO has a .05% annual fee, a bit better than SPY.  A quick few calculations show that the 10% bonus does offset a long run of the .75% excess expense compared to external investing. After decades, the 401(k) appears to still be a bit ahead. Not the dramatic delta suggested in the prior answer, but enough to stay with the 401(k) in this situation. The tiny match still makes the difference. Edit - the question you linked to. The 401(k) had no match, and an awful 1.2% annual expense. This combination is deadly for the younger investor. Always an exception to offer - a 25% marginal rate earner close to retiring at 15%. The 401(k) deposit saves him 25, but can soon be withdrawn at 15, it's worth a a few years of that fee to make this happen. For the young person who is planning a quick exit from the company, same deal.

instruction: Automatic investments for cheap
output: For your purposes, I would recommend using direct investment in a no-load mutual fund.  I mostly use Vanguard and would recommend them.  They just about invented index funds, usually have the lowest (internal) expenses for index and many other funds, if you take electronic instead of paper statements there is no maintenance fee, have no transaction commission, can do periodic automatic investment from a bank account etc.  A typical index fund there would require an initial $3000 investment and would have a minimum of $100 for each additional investment.  If you can't come up with an initial sum of that size, you might be able to find a broker with a lower minimum and suitable free ETFs trades as others have suggested.

instruction: Can travel expenses be deducted from Form 1040A if they were used to gather material for a book?
output: Hobby expenses are not tax deductible.  Business expenses are, but only if it's a bona fide business.  First they look at profitability: if you reported a net profit (i.e. paid taxes) in your first 3 years, they will believe you rant on Youtube for a living.   Remember, by the time they get around to auditing you, you'll likely be well into, or through, your third year.   There is an exception for farms.  Other than that, if you lose money year after year, you better be able to show that you look, walk and quack like a business; and one with a reasonable business reason for delayed profitability.  For instance Netflix's old business model of mailing DVDs had very high fixed infrastructure expense that took years to turn profitable, but was a very sensible model.  They're fine with that.  Pets.com swandived into oblivion but they earnestly tried. They're fine with that too.  You can't mix all your activities. If you're an electrician specializing in IoT and smart homes, can you deduct a trip to the CES trade show, you bet.  Blackhat conference, arguable.  SES?  No way.  Now if you had a second business of a product-reco site which profited by ads and affiliate links, then SES would be fine to deduct from that business.  But if this second business loses money every year, it's a hobby and not deductible at all.  That person would want separate accounting books for the electrician and webmaster businesses.  That's a basic "duck test" of a business vs. a hobby. You need to be able to show how each business gets income and pays expense separate from every other business and your personal life.  It's a best-practice to give each business a separate checking account and checkbook. You don't need to risk tax penalties on a business-larva that may never pupate.  You can amend your taxes up to 3 years after the proper filing date.  I save my expense reciepts for each tax year, and if a business becomes justifiable, I go back and amend past years' tax forms, taking those deductions.  IRS gives me a refund check, with interest!

instruction: Has anyone compared an in-person Tax Advisor to software like Turbo Tax?
output: I have fairly simple tax returns and my experience was that TurboTax software produced roughly the same result as human accountant and costs much less. The accountant was never able to find any deductions that the program couldn't find.  Of course, if you have business, etc. you probably need an accountant to help you navigate all the rules, requirements, etc. But for simple enough cases I found that the additional pay is not justified.

instruction: Long(100%)-Short(-100%) investment explanation
output: If you mean the percentages of long/short positions within a mutual fund or ETF, then it's a percentage of the total value of the fund portfolio. In that case, positions of 50% in X, -50% in Y are not the same as 100% in X, -100% in Y. If the long and short positions are both for the same asset, then, as D Stanley mentions, all that matters is the net position. If you're equally long and short X, then the net position is always 0%.

instruction: Why does gold have value?
output: Gold has very useful physical properties for some engineering applications.  Even tiny amounts of gold can substantially improve products, so it can be worthwhile to pay high prices per ounce for gold.  For example: Gold can be "beaten" or electroplated to produce very thin shiny coatings.  Entire roofs (of famous buildings) have been covered with "gold leaf", at a cost that was small compared to the supporting structure. A very thin layer of electroplated gold provides better protection against corrosion than a much thicker layer of electroplated nickel.  Even if gold costs thousands of times more per ounce than nickel, it is cheaper to use gold as an anti-corrosion layer than nickel (for use in military-grade naval electronics). A thin layer of electroplated gold greatly increases the electrical current-carrying capacity of a thin copper wire.

instruction: Strategy for investing large amount of cash
output: Getting the right diversity of investments helps buffer you from some of the short term market swings. If you need advice it's worth spending a small part of that money on a consultation with a financial adviser, who can talk to you about your goals, your time horizon, and your risk tolerance and recommend a good starting distribution. (Free advice from brokers risks being biased by their commissions.) Once you have that plan, uou need to decide how to execute it. Low-fee index funds are a good way to get started until you learn more, and for many of us that's all we ever need. Then you need to decide whether to invest it all at once or dollar-cost average. I've heard arguments both ways; DCA does mean you risk missing some immmediate gains, but also reduces your risk of buying at a temporary high and taking some immediate losses. For me DCA seemed to make sense, but that's another decision for you to make.

instruction: Foolish to place orders before the market opens?
output: More on a technical note, but the spread on an ETF tends to be worst at market open and near market close. (assuming the ETF constituents are traded on a synchronous basis.) If possible, it's often best to let market makers get up and running before allowing your order to flow into market.

instruction: If the housing market is recovering, why would a REIT index ETF (e.g. VNQ) not be performing well?
output: VNQ only holds ~16% residential REITs. The rest are industrial, office, retail (e.g. shopping malls), specialized (hotels perhaps?) etc.  Thus, VNQ isn't as correlated towards housing as you might have assumed just based on it being about "real estate." Second of all, if by "housing" you mean that actual houses have gone up appreciably, then you ought to realize that residential REITs seldom hold actual houses. The residential units held tend primarily to be rental apartments. There is a relationship in prices, but not direct.

instruction: How can I make $250,000.00 from trading/investing/business within 5 years?

instruction: First concrete steps for retirement planning when one partner is resistant
output: To answer your question: As far as what's available in addition to your 401(k) at work (most financial types will say to contribute up to the match first), you may qualify for a Roth IRA (qualification is based on income), if not, then you may have to go with a Traditional IRA.  You and your husband can each have one and contribute up to the limit each year.  After that, you could get just a straight up mutual fund, and/or contribute up to limit on your 401(k). My two cents: This may sound counter-intuitive (and I'm sure some folks will disagree), but instead of contributing to your 401(k) now, take whatever that amount is, and use it to pay extra on the car loan.  Also take the extra being paid on the mortgage and pay it on the car loan too.  Once the car loan is paid off, then set aside 15% of your gross income and use that amount to start your retirement investing.   Any additional money beyond this can then go into the mortgage.  Once it's paid off, then you can take the extra you were paying, plus the mortgage and invest that amount into mutual funds. You may want to check out Chris Hogan's Retire Inspired book or podcast as well.

instruction: Pros/cons of borrowing money using a mortgage loan and investing it in a low-fee index fund?
output: Risk is the problem, as others have pointed out. Your fixed mortgage interest rate is for a set period of time only. Let's say your 3% might be good for five years, because that's typical of fixed-rate mortages in Canada. So, what happens in five years if your investment has dropped 50% due to a prolonged bear market, and interest rates have since moved up from 3% to 8%? Your investment would be underwater, and you wouldn't have enough to pay off the loan and exit the failed strategy. Rather, you might just be stuck with renewing the mortage at a rate that makes the strategy far less attractive, being more likely to lose money in the long run than to earn any. Leverage, or borrowing to invest, amplifies your risk considerably. If you invest your own money in the market, you might lose what you started with, but if you borrow to invest, you might lose much more than you started with. There's also one very specific issue with the example investment you've proposed: You would be borrowing Canadian dollars but investing in an index fund of U.S.-based companies that trade in U.S. dollars. Even if the index has positive returns in U.S. dollar terms, you might end up losing money if the Canadian dollar strengthens vs. the U.S. dollar. It has happened before, multiple times. So, while this strategy has worked wonderfully in the past, it has also failed disastrously in the past. Unless you have a crystal ball, you need to be aware of the various risks and weigh them vs. the potential rewards. There is no free lunch.

instruction: How do 401k handle rate of return
output: A 401(k) is an investment just like any other investment. You generally get two types of return lumped into that number, but there can be more and you should read your funds prospectus carefully. If you aren't investing in direct companies, you're using mutual funds for instance, then you should read the funds prospectus to see how they handle these situations for the underlying securities they hold for you. Although I think this is the basic answer to the question as you asked.

instruction: Why not just invest in the market?
output: Most of it is probably due to ignorance and disbelief. A few years ago, I started doing week-long trades with my IRA. For a while I would make money each time, and over the first year I had about a 20% rate of return. If you asked me if I thought I was smarter than other people in the market, I would've told you no - I just spent more time, and most people accepted a small financial penalty for not having to spend the time directly managing their portfolio. Then I made a few poor choices, and all my previous earnings disappeared quickly. In the short term, yeah, things were great, but that didn't extrapolate out. So now that I'm a few years into investing, I'm almost entirely in index funds.

instruction: What exactly can a financial advisor do for me, and is it worth the money?
output: If you don't have the time or interest to manage investments, you need a financial advisor.  Generally speaking, you're better served by an advisor who collects an annual fee based on a percentage of your account value. Advisors who are compensated based on transactions have a vested interest to churn your account, which is often not in your best interest. You also need to be wary of advisors who peddle expensive mutual funds with sales loads (aka kick-backs to the advisor) or annuities. Your advisor's compensation structure should be transparent as well.

instruction: When does Ontario's HST come into effect?
output: It looks like the HST will be in effect in Ontario on July 1st, 2010.   As to whether it will replace GST with HST for all services, it looks like some sectors may get special treatment: Ontario may exempt mutual funds from HST (National Post).  But it doesn't look final yet. However, I would suggest that most service-based businesses in Ontario need to prepare to start charging 13% HST instead of 5% GST.  It will be the law. On the "goods" side of the new harmonized tax, it looks like certain goods will still be exempt from the provincial portion.  Here's a quote from the Ontario Budget 2009 News Release: "Books, diapers, children's clothing   and footwear, children's car seats and   car booster seats, and feminine   hygiene products would be exempt from   the provincial portion of the single   sales tax." Here's some additional information on the introduction of the HST, from the province: General Transitional Rules for Ontario HST. And finally, another interesting article from the Ottawa Business Journal: Preparing For Ontario Sales Tax Harmonization – It's Not Too Early  UPDATE: I just received an insert from Canada Revenue Agency included with my quarterly GST statement.  Titled "Harmonization of the Sales Tax in Ontario and British Columbia", it contains a section titled "What this means for you" (as in, you the business owner).  Here's an excerpt: [...] All Ontario and B.C. registrants would need to update their accounting   and point-of-sale systems to   accomodate the change in rate and new   point-of-sale rebates for the   implementation date of July 1, 2010. The harmonization of the sales tax in Ontario and B.C. may affect the   filing requirements of registrants   outside of these two provinces. Registrants will report their HST according to their current GST filing   frequency. As a result of the harmonization, there will be changes to the rebates   for housing and public service bodies. More information will be released as   it becomes available. Visit the CRA   web site often, at   www.cra.gc.ca/harmonization, for   the most up-to-date information on the   harmonization of the sales tax and how   it may affect you. [...] Last, I found some very detailed information on the HST here: NOTICE247 - Harmonized Sales Tax for Ontario and British Columbia - Questions and Answers on General Transitional Rules for Personal Property and Services.  Chances are anything you want to know is in there.

instruction: Does an index have a currency?
output: More importantly, index funds are denominated in specific currencies. You can't buy or sell an index, so it can be dimensionless. Anything you actually do to track the index involves real amounts of real money.

instruction: Long-term capital gain taxes on ETFs?
output: Generally, ETFs and mutual funds don't pay taxes (although there are some cases where they do, and some countries where it is a common case). What happens is, the fund reports the portion of the gain attributed to each investor, and the investor pays the tax. In the US, this is reported to you on 1099-DIV as capital gains distribution, and can be either short term (as in the scenario you described), long term, or a mix of both. It doesn't mean you actually get a distribution, though, but if you don't - it reduces your basis.

instruction: Pay index fund expense ratios with cash instead of fund balance
output: In many cases the expenses are not pulled out on a specific day, so this wouldn't work. On the other hand some funds do charge an annual or quarterly fee if your investment in the fund is larger than the minimum but lower than a "small balance" value. Many funds will reduce or eliminate this fee if you signup for electronic forms or other electronic services. Some will also eliminate the fee if the total investment in all your funds is above a certain level. For retirement funds what you suggest could be made more complex because of annual limits. Though if you were below the limits you could decide to add the extra funds to cover those expenses as the end of the year approached.

instruction: Buy small-cap ETF when you already have large-cap of the same market
output: Yes, you should own a diverse mix of company sizes to be well diversified. While both will probably get hit in a recession, different economies suit different sized companies very differently in many cases, and this diversity positions you best to not only not miss out in cases where small companies do better out of recessions than large, but also in environments where small companies rate of growth is larger in bull markets.

instruction: What is a mutual fund “high water mark” and how does it affect performance fees?
output: With the caveat that you should always read the fine print... Generally, the high water mark is the absolute highest mark at end of any quarter (sometimes month) over all the quarters (months) in the past.  Intra-quarter marks don't matter.   So, in your example the mark at the end of the second quarter would only be the new HWM if that mark is higher then the mark at the end of every previous quarter.  Again, what happened in the middle of of the second quarter doesn't matter. For hedge funds, the HWM may only be be from the date you started investing rather than over the whole history of the fund, but I would be surprised if that was true for any mutual funds.  Though, as I may have mentioned, it is worth reading the fine print.

instruction: Is a currency “hedged” ETF actually a more speculative instrument than an unhedged version?
output: Overall, since gold has value in any currency (and is sort of the ultimate reserve currency), why would anyone want to currency hedge it? Because gold is (mostly) priced in USD. You currency hedge it to avoid currency risk and be exposed to only the price risk of Gold in USD.  Hedging it doesn't mean "less speculative". It just means you won't take currency risk. EDIT: Responding to OP's questions in comment what happens if the USD drops in value versus other major currencies? Do you think that the gold price in USD would not be affected by this drop in dollar value? Use the ETF $GLD as a proxy of gold price in USD, the correlation between weekly returns of $GLD and US dollar index (measured by major world currencies) since the ETF's inception is around -47%. What this says is that gold may or may not be affected by USD movement. It's certainly not a one-way movement. There are times where both USD and gold rise and fall simultaneously. Isn't a drop in dollar value fundamentally currency risk? Per Investopedia, currency risk arises from the change in price of one currency in relation to another. In this context, it's referring to the EUR/USD movement. The bottom line is that, if gold price in dollar goes up 2%, this ETF gives the European investor a way to bring home that 2% (or as close to that as possible).

instruction: What are the pros and cons of investing in foreign markets?
output: The main rule of investing is finding the highest risk-adjusted capital return. Broadly speaking, an individual would seek to invest in a business where the profit is bigger than the overall risk taken.This is why diversification has proven to be one of the best ways to enhance risk-adjusted returns. It is believed that a diversified portfolio should hold at least eight uncorrelated assets that are spread across multiple areas, both industry-wise and geography-wise. Uncorrelated assets are those assets that are in no way related and do not influence one another. This means that in the eventuality of one investment failing, it will not affect the entire portfolio. Investing in foreign countries adds to geographical diversification and improves stability. Experts believe that one of the biggest mistakes investors make is to ignore the opportunities outside of their country. This includes small investors also, who don’t think they have portfolio sizable enough to include foreign investments. So index funds come to the aid of small investors by offering diversified foreign exposure.

instruction: Can I move my 401k to another country without paying tax penalty?

instruction: Are there any tax consequences I should be aware of when managing my wealth?
output:
If you invest in mutual funds, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and segregated fund contracts, you must report all taxable amounts related to these investments on your tax return each year. To help you complete your tax return, you’ll receive a tax slip that outlines the taxable amounts.

For an investment in a mutual fund trust, ETF, or segregated fund contract, you’ll receive a T3: Statement of Trust Income Allocations and Designations tax slip.
For an investment in a mutual fund corporation, you’ll receive a T5: Statement of Investment Income tax slip.
Residents of Quebec will also receive Relevé-16 (RL-16): Trust Income and Relevé-3 (RL-3): Investment Income tax slips respectively.
The information in this article will help you understand the information on your investment tax slips and reporting the taxable amounts on your tax return.

instruction: What's the most conservative split of financial assets for my portfolio in today's market?
output: Before investing, absolutely follow the advice in mbhunter's answer. There is no safe investment (unless you count your mattress, and even there you could find moths, theives, or simple inflation taking a chunk out of your change).  There is only maximizing your reward for a given level of risk - and there is always risk. This question should be enshrined somewhere on the Q&A site for its comprehensive list of sources for information on asset allocation.  The tag is also going to have tons of good information for you. To answer your question on what slice of the pie is devoted to what, you can check out some common portfolios given by U. S. experts for U. S. investors - these should be convertible into Australian funds. Another portfolio that is, like all those above, loosely based on Modern Portfolio Theory for maximizing reward for a given level of risk is the Gone Fishin' Portfolio. A common denominator amongst these portfolios is that they emphasize index funds over mutual funds for their long-term performance and preference lazy management (yearly rebalancing is a common suggestion as the maximum level of involvement) over active management.  You can see more Lazy Portfolios.

instruction: Can you help me find an ETF Selection website that evaluates my ETF holdings?
output: I used to use etfconnect before they went paid and started concentrating on closed end funds. These days my source of information is spread out. The primary source about the instrument (ETF) itself is etfdb, backed by information from Morningstar and Yahoo Finance. For comparison charts Google Finance can't be beat. For actual solid details about a specific ETF, would check read the prospectus from the managing firm itself. One other comment, never trust a site that "tells you" which securities to buy. The idea is that you need sources of solid information about financial instruments to make a decision, not a site that makes the decision for you. This is due to the fact that everyone has different strategies and goals for their money and a single site saying buy X sell Y will probably lead you to lose your money.

instruction: Is there a finance API of some kind to get all holdings for a specific mutual fund?
output: Generally, the answer to the availability of holdings of a given mutual fund on a daily basis is no. Thus, an API is non-existent. The reasons for the lack of transparency on a daily basis is that it could/would impact the portfolio managers ability to trade. While this information would not necessarily permit individuals from front running the fund manager's trades, it does give insight in to the market outlook and strategy the fund is employing. The closest you'll be able to get to obtaining a list of holdings is by reading the most recent annual report and the quarterly filings each fund is required to file with the SEC.

instruction: What are the risks with ETFs with relatively low market caps?

The spread is likely to be wider on lesser traded ETF funds we are talking about pennies, likely not an issue unless you are trading in and out frequently. The expense ratios will also tend to be slightly higher again not a huge issue but it might be a consideration. You are unlikely to make up the cost of paying the commission to buy into a larger ETF any time soon though.

Some of them will also let you practice with a demo account that let you invest virtual money to make you feel comfortable with the interface and also with investing in general.

instruction: How can I minimize the impact of the HST?
output: The HST is a sales tax levied on most goods and services. It is important to realize that in both BC and Ontario, the new HST does not (in most cases) result in an increase in sales tax paid. For example, in Ontario the PST is 8% and when combined with the GST the sales tax is 13%. With the HST, the GST and PST are replaced by a single HST of 13% so the tax bill does not change. Some services that were previously not subject to PST (such as mutual fund service fees and labour) will now be subject to the HST. So some things will increase. Over time, this should not have a material impact on the consumer due to the way businesses remit GST/HST.

instruction: Emerging markets index fund (VDMIX) for an inexperienced investor
output: In this environment, I don't think that it is advisable to buy a broad emerging market fund.  Why? "Emerging market" is too broad... Look at the top 10 holdings of the fund... You're exposed to Russia & Brazil (oil driven), Chinese and Latin American banks and Asian electronics manufacturing. Those are sectors that don't correlate, in economies that are unstable -- a recipie for trouble unless you think that the global economy is heading way up. I would recommend focusing on the sectors that you are interested in (ie oil, electronics, etc) via a low cost vehicle like an index ETF or invest using a actively managed emerging markets fund with a strategy that you understand.  Don't invest a dime unless you understand what you are getting into. An index fund is just sorting companies by market cap. But... What does market cap mean when you are buying a Chinese bank?

instruction: Describe the life and reign of King Charles II.
output: King Charles II ascended to the throne of England following the English Civil War and the death of his father, Charles I. He was crowned in 1661 and his reign lasted until his death in 1685. Charles II was also a patron of the arts, working with some of the greatest painters and sculptors of his day. He also encouraged theater and sports and had an interest in sciences such as astronomy and natural history. Charles II was a moderate ruler who respected the civil and religious liberties of his citizens. He was tolerant of other religions and gave Jews and Catholics more rights in the kingdom. Charles II was also a strong supporter of the Royal Navy, which saw England increase its power in the world. He also promoted the development of industry and commerce, which helped to modernize the country. Charles II's reign was an important step in restoring the monarchy of England after the turmoil of the English Civil War.

The US Bureau of Labor Statistics also reports that since April 2020, 43 million Americans have filed for unemployment. 

The US Federal Reserve reported in June 2020 that 40% of households making less than $40,000 a year had lost a job or experienced a reduction in income due to COVID-19, while 23% of households making over $100,000 had experienced job losses or income reductions.

instruction: Give a brief description of the coronavirus.
output: Coronavirus is a type of virus that can cause illnesses ranging from the common cold to severe diseases such as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). The virus is named for the crown-like spikes on its surface. It spreads primarily through close contact with an infected person, through small droplets from the nose or mouth after coughing or sneezing. Symptoms can include fever, tiredness, and dry cough. In severe cases, it can cause difficulty breathing, pneumonia, kidney failure, and even death.

instruction: Write a short biography about John F. Kennedy
output:
John Fitzgerald Kennedy, also known as JFK, was an American politician who served as the 35th President of the United States from 1961 to 1963. He was the youngest person ever elected president and the first Roman Catholic. JFK is remembered as a leader who challenged America to find its best self and worked tirelessly to improve civil rights and advance space exploration.

Born in 1917 in Massachusetts and raised in a wealthy family, JFK was exposed to politics at an early age. His father, Joseph P. Kennedy, served as the US ambassador to the United Kingdom. JFK attended Harvard University and graduated cum laude in 1940. Following his graduation, he served in the Navy and earned a Purple Heart for his heroism in a battle.

JFK first ran for public office in 1946, winning a seat in the House of Representatives. In 1952, he was elected to the Senate, becoming the youngest senator in history. In 1960, he pushed for a more progressive vision for the country in his presidential campaign, defeating Richard Nixon in the presidential election.

As president, Kennedy was responsible for introducing sweeping civil rights legislation and implementing major social policies. He pushed for America's space exploration and pushed against Soviet imperialism. He also initiated the first peace negotiation between the United States and the Soviet Union. 

JFK was assassinated in Dallas, Texas on November 22nd, 1963. His death shocked the world and he remains one of the most beloved presidents of all time. His words and decisions still shape the nation and the world at large.

instruction: Generate a story about a brave young girl.
output:
Once upon a time, there was a brave young girl named Amelia. She lived in a small village located in the heart of a great forest. Despite all the dangers of living in this dark and mysterious place, Amelia never allowed fear to stand in her way. 

One day, Amelia set out on an adventure deep into the depths of the forest. The further she went, the more treacherous the journey became. She encountered giant spiders, wild animals, and had to navigate her way through a dense and gloomy fog. But Amelia kept going, facing each challenge and danger with courage and bravery. 

Eventually, Amelia arrived at the edge of the forest where she discovered a hidden castle shrouded in mist. After a brief moment of hesitation, Amelia ventured inside, and soon discovered that the castle was filled with all sorts of magical monsters and creatures! 

Amelia was undeterred, however, and fought her way through the creatures as she searched for a way out. With the help of her courage and quick thinking, Amelia eventually managed to find her way out of the castle and made it safely back to the village. 

From that day forward, Amelia was known as a brave and courageous local hero, and the villagers always looked upon her with admiration and pride.

instruction: Summarize the timeline of important events leading to World War II.
output: World War II began in September 1939 when Germany invaded Poland. In April 1940, Germany invaded Scandinavia and then France in May. Germany then launched a major campaign against the Soviet Union in June 1941. In December 1941, Japan attacked the United States at Pearl Harbor, and the United States declared war on Japan the next day. In retaliation, Germany and Italy declared war against the United States. Throughout 1942, Germany was defeated on many fronts including in North Africa, the Atlantic, and the Eastern Front. In June 1944, Allies from both Europe and the Pacific invaded France in the largest amphibious invasion ever – D-Day. The Allies then advanced toward Germany, and by 1945, Soviet forces advanced through Germany and liberated Nazi concentration camps. Germany surrendered in May 1945 and Japan surrendered a few months later in September 1945, officially ending World War II.

instruction: Pick one of the following organisms and explain how it is adapted to its environment.
input: Blue Whale
output: The Blue Whale is a large, pelagic marine mammal with several adaptations that enable it to live in the open ocean. It has a huge tail to propel it forward, a streamlined body to reduce drag, and a network of blubber to keep it warm. The whale's blowhole is located at the top of its head, allowing it to take in air without having to stop and surface. Its extra wide mouth helps it to filter large amounts of ocean water and krill in a single gulp. Its powerful sonar enables it to navigate the environment, find prey, and send out sound communication.

instruction: Explain how self-driving cars work.
output: Self-driving cars are equipped with a combination of sensors, cameras, and software. The sensors detect the environment around the vehicle, measuring objects like traffic lights, lane markers, and other vehicles in the vicinity. The cameras help to compare the real-world environment with maps and other data. The software then interprets the data and provides instructions to the car’s actuators which control the throttle, brakes, and steering of the vehicle. Finally, the car is able to navigate without the need for a driver.

instruction: Create a fictional character using the Hero's Journey archetype.
output:
Alice is an ordinary young woman who leads a mundane life. She is content but dissatisfied, longing for something more. Then, she finds herself presented with an opportunity to embark on a grand adventure. Initially, she is hesitant, but as she realizes the potential of this journey, she accepts the challenge.

Alice enters the first stage of her journey, the Ordinary World, and finds herself being thrust into a completely foreign world. She meets a mentor, a wise old woman who guides her and teaches her the essential skills she needs in order to navigate the unknown territories that await her. Along the way, she faces many obstacles and hardships, both physical and emotional. Eventually, she succeeds in her quest and achieves her ultimate goal. She returns to her Ordinary World with newfound insight, experiences, and wisdom.

instruction: Write a short story with the title "The Throne".
output:
Lucia stood before the riverbank, riveted by the throne she saw on the other side. It was made of solid gold, shimmering with a mystic power. On the throne were two crowns, one made of gold and the other made of the purest silver. She hesitated, unsure of what to do next.

Suddenly, Lucia felt the presence of someone beside her. She turned to find an old wizard standing there, smiling softly and offering them both a chance at the throne. His voice, calm and wise, filled the air as he began with “Today, your destinies will be decided by the challenge ahead. I present to you for a fair fight: the throne of two crowns. Plus all bidding contenders will be granted one wish, as enigmatic as the throne itself.”

Lucia gulped. She knew no wishes without consequence, and she had no desire to be the victim of a power play. But fellow adventurers who lined up to take part in the challenge made her realize that the reward of ascending a throne was worth more than any wish.

Lucia stepped forward, joining the challenge with determination. Soon, she and her opponents began making crosses and chasms to get to the other side in a race to the throne. She used her agility to climb rocks, jumped on platforms to traverse seas, and navigated her way through dark tunnels. 

Eventually, Lucia was the first to ascend to the throne and was crowned Queen of two crowns. The adventure was difficult and filled with danger, but the power radiating from the throne was enough to make her forget all her worries. 

Lucia had earned the throne of two crowns, and she would never give it up.

Designing an intuitive user experience for a banking app involves creating a simple and easy-to-use interface that minimizes any confusion or complexity for customers. instruction: How do self-driving cars sense the world around them?
output: Self-driving cars use sensors to perceive the world around them, such as radar, lidar, cameras, and ultrasound. Radar and lidar use pulses of radio or light waves to detect the shape, size and speed of objects by measuring how long it takes for the waves to bounce off the object and return. Cameras are used to detect colors, shapes, and movements. Ultrasound is used to detect nearby objects or obstacles.  The data from these sensors is combined with artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms to enable self-driving cars to navigate their environment.

instruction: Summarize the history of the Peloponnesian War in no more than 100 words.

In between, Sparta had the upper hand, but both sides experienced periods of victory and played off one another, taking turns to gain the upper hand. The war saw strategies, tactics and siege warfare employed on a larger scale than ever before, and turned out to be a major event in Greek history.

instruction: Discuss the relationship between entropy and reversibility.
output: Entropy is a measure of disorder in a system. It is a measure of the amount of energy that is unavailable to do work. Reversibility is the ability of a system to return to its original state after it has undergone some change. A reversible system is one in which the entropy of the system can be completely restored to its original state after undergoing a change. Entropy and reversibility are related in that a system with a lower entropy is more likely to be reversible.

instruction: Give instructions on how to build a website.

Building a website can seem overwhelming, but it doesn't have to be. With the right tools and knowledge, anyone can create a website in just a few steps. Here's how to do it:

2. Develop a web design. Decide what kind of content you want to include on your website and how you want it to look. Consider font, color, images, and overall layout.
3. Create the content. This includes text, images, audio, and video. You'll want a mix of content that will attract and engage your audience, and make your website stand out from the competition.
4. Set up the structure of your website. Choose a content management system (CMS) such as WordPress to help you create a website structure. Set up menus and navigation for visitors to find content.
5. Publish your website. Once you have finished designing and writing content for your website, you can publish it by uploading the pages to your hosting provider. 

By following these steps, you'll be able to create a website that is both attractive and functional.

instruction: Research a topic and provide a summary report on it.
input: The impact of online streaming on traditional television viewing.
output: The impact of online streaming on traditional television viewing has been considerable. Online streaming services such as Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime have grown increasingly popular over the last decade, and this has had a major effect on traditional TV consumption. In particular, there has been a noticeable shift in television viewers away from linear TV and towards streaming services. This shift has led to an overall decrease in traditional television viewership, as well as a change in the types of content being consumed. For example, streaming services tend to offer much more variety and choice than traditional television channels, which has led to an increased focus on genres such as drama and comedy. Consequently, this has had an effect on the types of content being produced for traditional channels, with a greater focus on reality and sports programming. Overall, the prevalence of online streaming has certainly had an impact on traditional television viewing.

instruction: Summarize the events of the 1787 Constitutional Convention.
output: The 1787 Constitutional Convention was a gathering of leaders in Philadelphia led by George Washington where the Constitution of the United States was drafted and adopted. The delegates discussed a wide array of issues such as labor rights, navigation-rights, taxation, the representation of states in Congress and the form of the federal government. The convention concluded after four long months with the signing of the Constitution on September 17th. The document was then sent to the states for their respective ratifications. During the two years between then and now, the ultimate federal government was determined, and the Constitution was ratified by all thirteen states.

instruction: Write about the battle of Dunkirk.
output: The Battle of Dunkirk was an important conflict during World War II, when Allied Forces were surrounded by Nazi Germany in the north of France. The British Expeditionary Force, aided by French and Belgian soldiers, held off the Germans’ advance while British boats rescued hundreds of thousands of Allied soldiers from the beaches at Dunkirk. For nine days, the Allied forces fought hard, withstanding relentless German aerial assaults as well as land attacks. Thanks to great courage and tenacity, the British Navy managed to evacuate more than 330,000 Allied troops from the beaches of Dunkirk. Though the Allies were not successful in preventing the German military from overrunning France, the evacuation of Dunkirk marks one of the few bright points in the war, reminding us of the bravery of men from multiple countries fighting together against a formidable enemy.

instruction: How would artificial intelligence be used for helping the disabled?
output: Artificial intelligence can be used for helping the disabled in a variety of ways. For example, AI can be used to enable them to more efficiently complete tasks with technology that can understand their needs and activity levels. AI-based tools, such as speech and gesture recognition software, can be used by the disabled to access and interact with devices, applications, and websites, while applications powered by AI technologies, such as facial recognition and natural language processing, can be used to detect abnormalities in movement or speech patterns, or provide guidance to the disabled with adaptive navigation and automation. AI can also be used to develop applications to detect objects in the environment, predict trajectories and outcomes, recognizing facial and emotional expressions, and the generation of sign language translations, aiding those with hearing or sight impairments. AI can also be used for complex tasks such as modeling disease and disability, as well as predicting mobility needs of the disabled in order to provide personalized and adaptive support.

instruction: Section off the data into 5 categories identified by a 'red flag'
input: This dataset contains information about 100 student loan applications. For each application, there are 4 variables: age, FICO score, monthly income, and loan amount.
output:
The data can be sectioned off using a red flag criteria. Here are the 5 categories: 

Category 1: High-risk – Age below 21 years or FICO score below 600 or Monthly Income below $2000. 

Category 2: Medium-risk – Age 21–40 years, FICO score 600–665 and Monthly Income between $2000-$4999. 

Category 3: Low-risk – Age 41–55 years, FICO score 666–735 and Monthly Income between $5000-$7999.

Category 4: Very Low-risk – Age above 55 years and FICO score above 736. 

Category 5: Insufficient Data – FICO score and Monthly Income unavailable.

instruction: Explain the given process step-by-step.
input: Coronavirus vaccine development

instruction: Write an essay on success.
output:
Success is an elusive state of mind that is often hard to define. To some, success may mean achieving a certain goal or reaching a certain level of financial stability. To others, it may mean finding a purpose in life and beginning a journey of personal growth. Regardless of definition, the concept of success is best understood as a journey. Life’s successes come in many forms and largely depend on the individual’s dedication and commitment to reach personal satisfaction.

Finding success requires hard work and determination, and it is often good to seek advice and mentorship from those who have achieved success. Along with hard work and dedication, success is largely contingent on self-belief and the ability to turn failure into an opportunity to learn. Life is full of challenges and struggles, and it is often the mindset that helps individuals navigate through difficulties. Having a growth mindset is essential to success, as it provides the motivation and encourages individuals to step out of their comfort zone and to push their boundaries.

Success is ultimately personal and should be measured differently for each individual. It is important to remember that success is subjective and doesn’t have to mean big monetary gains or fame. When looking for success, it is worth reflecting on and understanding what truly makes one happy and fulfilled so that you can set specific, achievable goals.

instruction: generate a list of ten interesting things about a cat
output:
1. Cats' whiskers are extremely sensitive and are used to help them navigate in the dark or locate potential prey.
2. A domestic cat can sprint up to 31 miles per hour.
3. Cats have an incredibly powerful sense of smell and can smell up to 100 times better than humans.
4. Cats are able to survive falls from great heights by righting themselves and landing on their feet.
5. A cat's heart beats nearly twice as fast as a human heart.
6. Cats can jump up to 5 times their own height.
7. Cats groom themselves primarily with their tongue, which has tiny barbs on the end to help remove dirt and debris.
8. Cats can make over 100 different sounds, while humans and dogs can both only make around 10.
9. Cats sweat through the pads of their feet rather than through their skin.
10. Cats have twice as many neurons in the somatosensory region of the brain, meaning they have an exceptionally strong sense of touch.

instruction: Explain the historical significance of the Cuban Missile Crisis.
output: The Cuban Missile Crisis was a major confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cold War. It occurred in October 1962 and is considered one of the most critical moments of the Cold War due to the potential for nuclear conflict. The crisis was sparked by the discovery of Soviet-supplied nuclear missiles in Cuba, just 90 miles off the American coast. In response, the U.S. imposed a naval blockade on Cuba and threatened a full-scale invasion. After two weeks of tense negotiations, a deal was reached that involved the removal of all Soviet missiles from Cuba, in exchange for the withdrawal of American missiles from Turkey. The resolution of the Cuban Missile Crisis resulted in a major relief of international tensions and led to the implementation of nuclear-arms agreements that further reduced the risk of a global nuclear conflict.

instruction: Generate a creative story that describes an adventure in the jungle.
output:
Deep in the jungle, there was an adventure that was like no other. A brave girl named Pepper journeyed into the wild with her trusty guide, a curious parrot named Malibu. Together, they ventured across the treacherous terrain, navigating deep ravines and tall trees. 

Each step was a challenge and with each challenge, Pepper was determined to prevail. After hours of exploring, they finally encountered a hidden temple deep in the jungle. It was full of ancient artifacts and mysterious symbols. As Pepper explored the ruins, Malibu observed from afar, occasionally squawking in mischief. 

Eventually, Pepper discovered a secret chamber within the temple. What lay in the chambers was more surprising than anything Pepper could have ever expected; a mysterious ancient artifacts, a diamond as big as her fist!

instruction: Compare satellite navigation and Global Positioning System (GPS)
output: Satellite navigation and Global Positioning System (GPS) are both navigation systems that use data from orbiting satellites. GPS is the most widely used navigation system, as it is accurate to within a few meters. On the other hand, satellite navigation is becoming increasingly available and can provide real-time navigation assistance. It is generally not as accurate as GPS, but is still adequate for everyday navigation applications. Both systems receive signals from at least three orbiting satellites to triangulate their location.

instruction: Tell me about the bone structure of a human foot.
output: The human foot has 26 bones, which are divided into three categories: tarsals, metatarsals, and phalanges. The tarsals form the heel and midfoot, and consist of the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and three cuneiform bones. The metatarsals form the bridge of the foot and consist of five long bones. Finally, the phalanges are 14 long, small bones that make up the toes.

instruction: Explain the biological adaptation of the cassowary bird.
output: The cassowary is a large and powerful bird native to Indonesia, New Guinea, and northeastern Australia. Its strong legs and feet are well adapted for navigating the dense rainforest undergrowth. Its distinctive three-toed feet are equipped with sharp claws that allow it to jump over obstacles, climb steep slopes, and forage for food. Its unique physiology also helps to regulate its body temperature during the hot and humid conditions in the tropical regions where it lives. In addition, its brightly colored feathers are used to warn other birds and predators of its presence. Cassowaries use their sharp claws to defend themselves from potential predators, and their heavy bodies provide stability when they are running. Furthermore, the cassowary's food-digesting system is adapted to process the large variety of fruits and soft vegetation that makes up a large part of its diet.

instruction: Explain why the internet has become such an important tool.

instruction: Explain what is a DDoS attack.
output: A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack is a malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a server, network, or website. It is done by flooding the target with more traffic than it can handle, in an effort to overwhelm the system and make it unavailable to legitimate users. The attack usually originates from multiple sources, hence the term distributed.

instruction: How does my car's dashboard works?
output: Your car's dashboard consists of several meters, warning lights and gauges which help you monitor the performance of your car as you drive. These gauges include an odometer for tracking the distance traveled, a tachometer for monitoring the engine's speed, a speedometer for tracking your cars speed, an oil pressure gauge for keeping an eye on your car's oil levels, a thermometer to monitor the engine temperature and other gauges that display different types of information to the driver. Warning lights will alert when the vehicle needs maintenance, such as low oil and low fuel levels. Modern cars also offer several more advanced features such as navigation systems, Bluetooth and audio controls, as well as climate control systems.

instruction: Give me information about the Three Gorges Dam.
output: The Three Gorges Dam is located on the Yangtze River in the Hubei province of China and is the world's largest hydroelectric power plant. The Three Gorges Dam project was approved in 1992 and the construction began in 1994. The main purpose of the dam is to generate electrical power and control flooding of the lower Yangtze river. It is also used to facilitate navigation conditions on the Yangtze. The dam is 2,335 meters long and 185 meters high, with a reservoir capacity of 39.3 billion cubic meters. The dam has generated over 82.8 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity since its completion in 2012.

instruction: Generate a list of appropriate safety precautions to take while sailing.

The title of the blog post is: "The Economic Impact of Coronavirus: How this Global Pandemic is Affecting the Global Economy".

The global spread of Coronavirus has caused an unprecedented disruption to our lives, economies and financial markets. Many businesses have been forced to temporarily close or significantly reduce activities, leading to an increase in unemployment and a decrease in consumer spending. With governments imposing large-scale restrictions to reduce the spread of the virus, the near-term economic outlook appears bleak. This blog post looks at the effects of the pandemic on the global economy, and the steps being taken by governments to mitigate the economic effects of the crisis.

instruction: Construct a 500-character essay on a given topic.
input: The benefits of technology in transportation.
output: Technology has made an incredible impact on the transportation industry in recent years. Autonomous vehicles, improved navigation and route planning, and new methods of monitoring and managing traffic patterns have all made travel much easier and safer. Autonomous vehicles, like self-driving cars, are especially important, as they can increase safety and reduce the number of accidents that occur on the roads. Additionally, by utilizing GPS tracking, navigation and route planning, drivers can ensure their route is the most efficient and accurate. Finally, advanced traffic monitoring allows drivers to be aware of the current traffic conditions and plan their route accordingly. All of these technological advances have helped to make transportation much more efficient and safe.

instruction: Provide a scientific definition of entropy.
output: Entropy is a thermodynamic quantity that measures the amount of disorder or randomness of a system, and can be used to measure the amount of energy that is unavailable for work in a closed system.

instruction: Are there any similarities between a whale and a bat?
output: Yes, both whales and bats are mammals. They both give birth to live young and provide them with milk from the mother's mammary glands. Additionally, both whales and bats are endothermic, meaning their body temperature is regulated by their metabolism. Another similarity between whales and bats is that both use echolocation to navigate their environment. Finally, both whales and bats are highly social animals and live and travel in groups.

instruction: How did the invention of the telescope lead to space exploration?
output: The invention of the telescope in the early 17th century revolutionized our view of the universe. For the first time, astronomers were able to observe distant stars and planets, and began to understand their locations and movements. This enabled the development of more sophisticated models of the universe and eventually led to space exploration. With a better understanding of the solar system, scientists were able to create reliable methods for the navigation and propulsion of spacecraft. This allowed them to begin sending probes and missions to other planets and explore the universe.

instruction: Compose an essay analyzing the role of fate in the novel "The Alchemist"
output:
The idea of fate is a powerful and pervasive theme throughout Paulo Coelho's novel "The Alchemist", as the protagonist, Santiago, undertakes his quest in search of his Personal Legend. The concept of fate is most certainly tied to Santiago's journey and the purpose it serves, especially in the way it influences his decisions, as he believes following his destiny will lead him to success.

Throughout Santiago's journey, he is faced with a number of decisions and opportunities, which must be navigated with the knowledge that fate will depict the outcome. On his journey, Santiago meets a variety of characters, including the king and the gypsy, and as he listens to their advice, it's clear he is making decisions in faith that fate will pave the way. This is particularly notable in the case of the Alchemist, who directs him in his mission. We are told that Santiago's heart leads him "only to those things that it had always yearned for" – that is, his destiny.

It is clear from the novel that Santiago's choice to journey in search of his Personal Legend is a path destined for adventure, risk, and more importantly, fulfillment. One of the most remarkable occurrences in the novel is Santiago's journey through the desert, where he relies on fate to protect him from any harm.Here, fate serves as a reminder of Santiago's faith in his ultimate destiny, which leads him to his Personal Legend. 

The idea of fate is a powerful concept in "The Alchemist", as Santiago follows his destiny to prove that "wherever your heart is, there you will find your treasure". In the end, Santiago not only discovers his own treasure, but also finds something much deeper and more meaningful – the true understanding of his own fate.

instruction: Generate a list of 10 tips for overcoming social anxiety.
output:
1. Recognize Your Negative Thoughts: Identify negative thoughts that feed your social anxiety and replace them with more positive, realistic thoughts. 
2. Challenge Your Negative Thoughts:Expand your perspective and ask yourself questions that help to challenge your negative thoughts. 
3. Prepare for Social Situations: Learning about the social environment you are about to enter can help you feel more comfortable and make it easier to navigate the situation. 
4. Set Small Goals: Aim to focus on one thing at a time, and start with goals that feel relatively achievable. 
5. Stay Grounded: Use grounding techniques, such as deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation, to help center yourself in the present moment. 
6. Talk to Others: Talking to people you trust and rely on can help to remind you that you are not facing your social anxiety alone and can provide support and advice.
7. Stay Connected: Connecting with other people through activities like virtual hangouts and even writing can help to combat feelings of loneliness and inadequacy.  
8. Practice Self-Care: Take time for yourself and engage in activities that uplift your mood and give you a sense of purpose. 
9. Seek Professional Help: If your social anxiety has become too hard to bear, don’t hesitate to seek professional help from a therapist or qualified mental health provider. 
10. Choose Compassion: Instead of treating yourself harshly and harshly, be gentle and show yourself the same type of compassion that you would show another person.

instruction: What were two repercussions of the coronavirus pandemic on the education system?
output: The two biggest repercussions of the coronavirus pandemic on the education system have been the move to digital learning and the widening of educational disparities. The shift to online/virtual learning has had both positive and negative impacts on students, teachers, and parents, but it has created significant disruptions and challenges for many. Furthermore, the pandemic has exacerbated existing educational disparities by pushing students from lower-income families behind even further due to limited access to technology and internet connections. In some cases, the gap between students from low- and high-income backgrounds has grown significantly.

instruction: Describe the need for digital literacy in today's world.
output: The need for digital literacy in today's world is increasing rapidly due to the ever-evolving digital landscape. With more and more information and tasks being done online, having the skills to confidently navigate the internet and keep up with technology is essential. Digital literacy enables individuals to understand the risks associated with online activities and take the necessary steps to protect themselves. Additionally, digital skills are important for finding and evaluating reliable information, as well as for staying up to date with new technology and technological advancements. Having digital literacy also enables individuals to take advantage of the many benefits that technology has to offer, such as providing access to online learning, social connections, and valuable resources.
